disparate clusters that don't talk to each other and they can't utilize the shared resources this is okay on a daily
basis when they're doing smaller jobs but when they really want to run significant impactful science they don't
have nearly enough resources to perform the jobs that they need to do so they'll
come to our group and what we'll typically do since we're not a software development company we'll just come up with a homegrown solution uh that a
separate external system that will allow them to run their large simulations in the cloud utilizing Cloud
resources this is a completely separate system so it needs to remain heavily involved with the entire product life

partnered with cycle to implement the submit once technology now Taylor's going to talk in more detail about how
it works but the main uh important benefits from this is the user is
allowed to use the existing submission portal or command line utility that they
use to submit their jobs and submit once does all the work on the back end as to whether or not these jobs should be
submitted to their internal clusters that are already existing or burst out into the cloud if they are larger jobs
that will need a lot more uh compute resources this means that it does not
need to remain heavily involved because the administration of the system is the exact same as they've always has been
doing with her submission tools um so this is a win-win for both it and our scientific Partners uh so I'm going to
hand it over to Taylor Who's going to talk about how uh the submit once technology actually

uh with the client uh submitting their jobs uh as Kurt mentioned this can happen either through uh command line

some customers who don't have a a local uh Grid in place already and so uh the
jobs just head straight out to the cloud where we have a cluster set up for them uh or if they do have a local grid then
